intro: Antholoma montana, commonly known as the mountain antholoma, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes parsley and carrots, and is characterized by its slender, branched stems and small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or alpine environments, where it thrives in well-drained soils and cool climates. Its foliage is usually finely divided, and the flowers are white or pale yellow, contributing to its ornamental value in horticulture. Antholoma montana is of interest to botanists due to its unique adaptations to high-altitude habitats.
